title: 109_s2475
content: The Act titled "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006" establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. Voting members are appointed by the President and congressional leaders, while nonvoting members are appointed by congressional leaders. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. Members shall be chosen based on a demonstrated commitment to the research, study, or promotion of American Latino life, art, history, political or economic status, or culture, with expertise in museum administration, fundraising for nonprofit or cultural institutions, or teaching of Latino studies. The Commission seeks individuals with expertise in museum administration, fundraising for cultural institutions, teaching Latino culture and history, studying Smithsonian's representation of American Latino art, or experience in public service. Additionally, candidates with experience in administering or planning museums focused on ethnic groups in American history are also desired. The Commission seeks individuals with expertise in museum administration, fundraising for cultural institutions, teaching Latino culture and history, studying Smithsonian's representation of American Latino art, or experience in public service. Candidates with experience in administering or planning museums focused on ethnic groups in American history are also desired. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will develop fundraising plans and examine issues such as collection availability and the Museum's impact on regional Hispanic communities. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress on issues related to the establishment of a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. This includes examining collection availability, impact on regional Hispanic museums, possible locations, governance structure, and community engagement. The Commission will submit recommendations to Congress on the establishment of a National Museum of the American Latino Community, including its location within the Smithsonian Institution, governance structure, and community engagement. The Commission will convene a national conference on the Museum, involving individuals dedicated to American Latino life, art, history, and culture, within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of the Interior will provide necessary administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission. Members not federal employees may receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary. The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment and terminate within 30 days of submission. $2.1 million is authorized for fiscal year 2007 and $1.1 million for fiscal year 2008 for Commission activities.
